trans-unit.source: Creates a user interface element that enables users to invoke ASP.NET event handlers and it provides a means to post user input from UI elements back to the server.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control displays as an interactive UI element on the requesting device.
The label of the UI element comes from the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextControl.Text%2A> property, which is inherited from the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextControl> base class.
Avoid using special characters in ASP.NET mobile Web page URLs.
The HREF tags generated for posting `Command` events back to the server are not strictly validated.
For example, a URL that includes spaces results in the generation of WML that cannot be handled by some WML browsers.
Creates an instance of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command"></xref> class.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Gets or sets whether the specified control causes server-side validation to occur on all controls on the form.
The default value is `true`.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

For validation to occur on a form, the form must be submitted with a control that raises validation, and must have its <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.CausesValidation%2A> property set to `true`.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control is currently the only control that raises validation.
`true` if the specified control causes server-side validation to occur on all controls on the form; otherwise, `false`.
Occurs when a user activates a <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command"></xref> control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
When a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control is activated, it raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.OnClick%2A> event.
For more information, see the "Device-Specific Rendering" and "Device-Specific Behavior" sections in <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command?displayProperty=fullName>.
Sets or returns the argument associated with the command in the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.ItemCommand"></xref> event.
The default value is an empty string ("").
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The argument associated with the command in the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.ItemCommand"></xref>.
Gets or sets the command name associated with the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command"></xref> control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The name of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command"></xref> that raised the event.
Gets or sets the render style for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command"></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Access the two available types through the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.CommandFormat> enumeration.
<xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.CommandFormat?displayProperty=fullName> (default)
The command is rendered as a button.
The command is rendered as a link.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.Format%2A> property supports the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.CommandFormat?displayProperty=fullName> value only on devices that support JavaScript as indicated by the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.HttpCapabilitiesBase.JavaScript%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property.
A <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.CommandFormat"></xref> value indicating the render style for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command"></xref>.
Sets or returns the URL of the image source for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command"></xref> control when the control is rendered as an image button.
The default value is <xref href="System.String.Empty"></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
If this property is not <xref:System.String.Empty> and the device can handle image buttons, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control uses the image instead of a button or link text.
The URL of the image source for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command"></xref> when the control is rendered as an image button.
Gets a value indicating whether the control submits the form.
The default is `false`.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Mobile controls, such as the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command>, can override this method to determine whether this is a control used for form submission.
Other controls can be extended by providing logic to programmatically determine whether or not they must be submit controls, for example, by checking for specific properties.
A control is considered to be a form-submit control only if it implements <xref:System.Web.UI.IPostBackEventHandler> method to capture the postback event.
Otherwise, it is not registered for the default event handler, even if the method returns `true`.
`true` if the control submits the form; otherwise, `false`.
Occurs when the user selects a command that is associated with an <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.ObjectList"></xref> item.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

When an <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.ItemCommand> event handler is defined, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control notifies the handler when an item event is generated through user interaction.
Unlike the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.Click> event, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.ItemCommand> event is bubbled up to the parent controls.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.ItemCommand> event rendering is device-specific and is discussed in detail in the "Device-Specific Behavior" section of <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command?displayProperty=fullName>.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.OnItemCommand%2A> event is raised after an <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.OnClick%2A> event.

In a scenario where you repeat the same set of actions each time a command button is clicked, you can use either the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.CommandName%2A> or <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.CommandArgument%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control to identify which command button the user clicked.
Gets a value indicating whether the adapter associated with the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command"></xref> control has handled loading the post data.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This method is called by the <xref:System.Web.UI.IPostBackDataHandler.LoadPostData%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method.
Different devices might provide their data back to the calling server in different ways.
A reference to the name of a parameter collection.
A parameter collection of postback data.
`true` if the adapter associated with this control has handled loading the post data; otherwise, `false`.
Called when the user activates the control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The default implementation of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.OnClick%2A> method raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.Click> event.
Inheriting classes can override the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.OnClick%2A> method to perform other tasks.
An object defined by an <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that contains event data.
Called when the user activates the control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The default implementation raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.ItemCommand> event.
Inheriting classes can override this method to perform other tasks.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.OnItemCommand%2A> event is raised after the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.OnClick%2A> event.
This is useful when you must take the same actions for multiple <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> buttons.

You can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.CommandName%2A> or <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.CommandArgument%2A> property of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control to identify which <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> button was clicked.
An <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.CommandEventArgs"></xref> object that contains event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Web.UI.Control.PreRender"></xref> event.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> object that contains event data.
Raises events for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command"></xref> control when it posts back to the server.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.RaisePostBackEvent%2A> method is used internally by the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control when it is clicked to raise a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.Click> event.
The argument for the event.
Notifies the ASP.NET application that the state of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command"></xref> control has changed.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.RaisePostDataChangedEvent%2A> method can be overridden in a derived class to raise change events for the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control when it posts back to the server.
This method is used primarily by control developers.
Sets or returns the label used when a softkey is displayed.
The default value is an empty string ("").
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This property is used only for devices that support softkeys.
If this property is empty, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextControl.Text%2A> property of the control is used.

If the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextControl.Text%2A> property is empty or its length is less than 9, the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextControl.Text%2A> property is used for the softkey label.
Otherwise, the word `Go` (if it is a submit control command) is displayed.
The value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.SoftkeyLabel%2A> property is truncated to 12 characters (the standard maximum length of a softkey).
The label used when a soft key is displayed.
For a description of this member, see <xref href="System.Web.UI.IPostBackDataHandler.LoadPostData(System.String,System.Collections.Specialized.NameValueCollection)"></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This member is an explicit interface member implementation.
It can be used only when the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> instance is cast to an <xref:System.Web.UI.IPostBackDataHandler?displayProperty=fullName> interface.
A reference to the name of a parameter collection.
A parameter collection of postback data.
`true` if the adapter handles loading the post data; otherwise, `false`.
For a description of this member, see <xref href="System.Web.UI.IPostBackDataHandler.RaisePostDataChangedEvent"></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This member is an explicit interface member implementation.
It can be used only when the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> instance is cast to an <xref:System.Web.UI.IPostBackDataHandler> interface.
Raises events for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command"></xref> control when it posts back to the server.
For a description of this member, see <xref href="System.Web.UI.IPostBackEventHandler.RaisePostBackEvent(System.String)"></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.RaisePostBackEvent%2A> method is used internally by the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command> control when it is clicked to raise a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Command.Click> event.
The argument for the event.
